factoid: Denísov addressed his friend saying 'You see, my friend'.
Denísov said 'we sleep when we don’t love'.
Denísov said 'we are children of the dust'.
Denísov said 'but one falls in love and one is a God'.
Denísov said 'one is pua’ as on the first day of creation'.
Denísov asked 'Who’s that now?'.
Denísov told Lavrúshka to send the friend to the devil.
Denísov was busy.
Lavrúshka went up to Denísov not in the least abashed.
Denísov asked 'Who should it be?'.
Denísov said 'You yourself told the friend to come'.
Denísov said 'The quartermaster is for the money'.
Denísov frowned.
Denísov was about to shout a reply but stopped.
Denísov muttered 'Wetched business' to himself.
Denísov asked Rostóv 'How much is left in the purse?'.
Rostóv replied 'Seven new and three old imperials'.
Denísov said 'It’s wetched!'.
Denísov shouted 'Call the quartermaster' to Lavrúshka.
Rostóv offered to lend Denísov money.
Denísov said he does not like bowing to his own fellows.
Rostóv repeated that he has some money.
Denísov said 'No, I tell you'.
Denísov went to the bed to get the purse from under the pillow.
Denísov asked Rostóv 'Where have you put the purse?'.
Rostóv said the purse was under the lower pillow.
Denísov said the purse was not there.
Denísov threw both pillows on the floor.
The purse was not on the floor.
Denísov said 'That’s a miracle'.
Rostóv asked if Denísov had dropped the purse.
Rostóv picked up the pillows one at a time and shook them.
Rostóv pulled off the quilt and shook it.
The purse was not on the quilt.
Rostóv said he remembered thinking that Denísov kept the purse under his head like a treasure.
Rostóv said he put the purse just here and asked where it was.
Rostóv turned to Lavrúshka.
Lavrúshka said she had not been in the room and that the purse must be where Rostóv put it.
Lavrúshka said 'But it isn’t?'.
Lavrúshka said Denísov always throws things down anywhere and forgets them, and he should feel in his pockets.
Rostóv said he had thought of the purse being a treasure.
Rostóv said he remembered putting the purse there.
Lavrúshka turned all the bedding over, looked under the bed and under the table, searched everywhere, and stood still in the middle of the room.
Denísov silently watched Lavrúshka's movements.
Denísov glanced at Rostóv.
Rostóv said 'Wostóv, you’ve not been playing schoolboy tricks'.
Rostóv felt Denísov’s gaze fixed on him, raised his eyes, and instantly dropped them again.
All the blood that had seemed congested below Rostóv's throat rushed to his face and eyes.
Rostóv could not draw breath.
Rostóv said there had not been anyone in the room except the lieutenant and themselves, and that the purse must be here somewhere.
Lavrúshka said 'Now then, you devil’s puppet, look alive and hunt for it!'.
Denísov shouted that if the purse wasn’t found he would flog everyone.
Rostóv avoided Denísov's eyes and buttoned his coat, buckled his saber, and put on his cap.
Denísov said he must have the purse.
Denísov shook his orderly by the shoulders and knocked him against the wall.
Rostóv said 'Denísov, let him alone, I know who has taken it'.
Denísov paused, thought, and seized Rostóv's arm.
Denísov cried 'Nonsense!' and veins on his forehead and neck stood out like cords.
Denísov said 'You are mad, I tell you. I won’t allow it'.
Denísov said the purse is here, he will flay the scoundrel alive, and it will be found.
Rostóv repeated that he knows who has taken it.
Denísov shouted 'And I tell you, don’t you dahe to do it!'.
Denísov rushed at the cadet to restrain him.
